description.narrative: Sveriges regering har bekräftat sitt stöd för verksamheten vid FN:s högkommissarie för mänskliga rättigheter i Colombia (2017--2021) med ett totalt bidrag på 62 600 000 SEK. Det övergripande målet för insatsen är att låna ut allmänt stöd till verksamheten vid UNHCR:s kontor i Colombia.

The Government of Sweden has confirmed its intention to support the operations of the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights in Colombia (2017-2021) with a total contribution of SEK 62 600 000. The overall aim of contribution will be to lend general support to the operations of OHCHR’s Office in Colombia.

description.narrative: Summary of Results The Covid-19 pandemic in Colombia led to a series of measures to address the health emergency, including a presidential decree on 25 March ordering a preventive isolation or quarantine. The United Nations system began to restrict missions a couple of weeks before this measure was taken and instated work from home, which was maintained until the end of the year. The pandemic has had a significant impact on OHCHR’s work with the communities, making it necessary to create new forms of interacting. One the one hand, communities in the most remote regions find themselves more unprotected than ever, due not only to the confinement imposed by the pandemic during most of the year, but also the violence generated by armed actors in their efforts to increase their control of the territories. In addition, the existing structural inequalities in the effective enjoyment of human rights became much more evident. For this reason, the work throughout the year consisted in virtual meetings with local and national authorities as well as local and national social organizations. The purpose of the activities was to increase capacities and bring authorities and civil society closer together. OHCHR also carried out high-level virtual meetings to build strategic partnerships with Colombian institutions, in accordance with its mandate. Finally, the OHCHR team had the opportunity to position itself as a trustworthy stakeholder in the dialogues between Colombian authorities and civil society to discuss sensitive issues. Despite the preventive isolation, the Office has monitored cases and participated in an important number of meetings, as previously mentioned. Connectivity problems made it difficult to continue activities with the communities targeted by the Office. In 2020, the Office recorded advances in the work of the SIVJRNR, as well as an increase in public discourse aimed at undermining the legitimacy and credibility of the System. These included the introduction of legislative reports to modify the JEP, public statements by former officials and congresspersons against SIVJRNR representatives, and social network misinformation campaigns against the JEP. OHCHR met with the heads of the transitional mechanisms in October. The High Commissioner ratified the importance of transitional justice for the consolidation of peace and urged the authorities to cooperate with the SIVJRNR. The Memorandum of Understanding between the Office and the JEP was renewed in May. The Office also analyzed the trends and patterns of the cases of alleged arbitrary deprivation of the right to life, identifying the human rights issues that led to these violations, thus facilitating preventive actions to contribute to the prevention of these violations. In this context, the Office supported the establishment of thematic round-tables with the Ministry of Defense to analyze the problem and promote the adoption of international standards on prevention. Facts and figures: OHCHR Colombia undertook around 183 missions to monitor HR situations. There was a considerable decrease compared to other years due to the COVID-19 emergency. OHCHR Colombia monitored 13 trials in 2020. OHCHR Colombia visited 3 places of detention in 2020 OHCHR Colombia organized approximately 798 capacity-building workshops/trainings with public entities, civil society organizations, victims and ethnic people in 2020. Around 12.150 people attended: 6.440 women and 5.710 men. At least 679 of the workshops (85% approximately) were held online. Approximately 3 detainees were released at least partially as a result of UN Human Rights intervention in 2020. Disaggregation by sex and target is not available at this stage. During 2020 OHCHR Colombia communicated and positioned the impact of its work by: Issuing the publication of 5,056 press, radio, and television notes, through free presswork with the communications media. Four (4) campaigns: Covid 19, Human Rights Defenders, Lidera la Vida, and International Human Rights Day on 10 December. 45 videos, two of the Representative reading the press communiqués, in order to disseminate human rights in full HD During 2020 OHCHR Colombia distributed 44.996 publications/promotional materials.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
